trentKim.name: Writing
trentKim.description:
March 2, 2022. 9:10 pm. I’m crouched knees between my arms in my desk chair ignoring the churning of an empty stomach, while the soundtrack of C’mon C’mon creates the melancholy ambiance I enjoy while writing. This evening I’ve begun three iterations of a website introduction that I have each promptly given up on. My third attempt was the closest to the conveying the experiences in which my work is grounded in, but I caught myself trying to forcibly wax poetics and meaning into it (and I hear myself still trying to as I write this). I usually stop writing at that realization, but in the end, something made sense. That a people is embodied within the voice, not the language.

In my third iteration, I said, “To lose a language means it is something recoverable. But to lose a language means to grieve it as well”. It is a contradiction has defined my understanding of my grief, as language, as Korean, feels intrinsically tied to a people, to an ancestry, to a history, to a sense of collective grief yet resiliency— to family. For me, language can feel like exile from a self and from a people who I cannot communicate. But at the same time, my history, that of a transnational adoptee, originates from the same painful history of colonization, separation, war, loss, capitalism, and patriarchy. There in fact is not a contradiction, as language can be loss, but to be recoverable implies hierarchy— to be recoverable implies that I’ll eventually be satisfied. A people is embodied within the voice, not the language. The only language that is and has always been enough is the voice.
